title: Engine - Removal

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
The engine assembly is very heavy.
Get the help of an assistant and use the correct lifting equipment when you move the engine and transmission.
Make sure that the engine assembly is secured and cannot fall during removal or installation.
If the engine assembly is not secured, it can fall and cause injury.
To prevent damage to the sump, position wooden blocks between the jacks and the sump.
Secure the coolant hoses to prevent damage as the engine is removed.
Support the engine on proprietary lifting jacks, at the front and rear. Use wooden blocks to prevent damage to the sump.
Secure the engine to the jacks, using suitable straps, to prevent it from moving or falling as it is removed.
Note the position of the gear change crank on the gearbox shaft.
Disconnect the gear change linkage at the gearbox shaft. If Triumph Shift Assist (TSA) is fitted, temporarily tie the shift force sensor aside.
Set the drive chain adjustment to allow maximum free play in the chain, (see
Disconnect the electrical connector for the oxygen sensor, located near the front sprocket.
Detach the drive chain from the front sprocket and remove it.
Remove the two fixings and the left heel guard.
Remove the two fixings and the right heel guard.
Do not fully remove the swinging arm spindle.
If the swinging arm spindle is fully removed, the swinging arm can drop and cause injury or damage to the motorcycle.
Partly remove the swinging arm spindle sufficiently to release the engine.
Remove the three fixings that attach the right control plate and tie the control plate aside.
Slacken the cable lock nut and release the adjuster at the clutch cover end to give maximum play in the cable.
Release the clutch cable from the actuating arm by pushing the inner cable nipple through the arm and sliding the cable out of the slot. Detach the cable from the bracket.
Remove the two fixings that attach the left control plate and remove the control plate.
Disconnect the hose from the purge valve to the throttle bodies.
Remove the two fixings that attach the connector bracket and the connector tab to the breather cover.
Remove the rubber band that attaches the harness from the alternator to the regulator rectifier, to the fuel hose.
Release the fuel hose from the connector bracket and remove the hose.
Release the connectors from the connector bracket.
Disconnect the electrical connectors for the alternator and the side stand switch.
Disconnect the electrical connectors from the oil pressure switch and the coolant temperature sensor.
Some wires and hoses shown removed for clarity.
Release the electrical connector for the crank position sensor from the bracket on the starter motor.
Disconnect the engine harness from the main harness and remove the engine harness.
Remove the nut that attaches the ground cable to the rear of the crankcase and move the ground cable aside.
Release the rubber band that holds the cables together at the left side of the engine.
Where fitted, disconnect the electrical connector for the shift assist sensor and remove the shift assist sensor.
Note the routing of the cable for the gear position sensor.
Remove the cable tie that holds the harness for the gear position sensor to the electrical connector.
Remove the top fixing that attaches the wire guide for the gear position sensor harness.
Disconnect the electrical connector for the gear position sensor.
Disconnect the positive cable from the starter solenoid, to the starter motor (see
Use the jacks to support the weight of the engine .
Note the positions of the spacers at the engine mounting points.
Remove the rear lower bolt and collect the chain guide.
Loosen the left and right frame adjusters at the lower rear engine mountings.
Loosen but do not remove the left and right rear cylinder head fixings.
Remove the two front cylinder head fixings and washers. Collect the spacer from the right side.
Use the jacks to pivot the rear of the engine down. When the front cylinder head mountings are clear, remove the rear cylinder head fixings and lower the engine down.

Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Perform the following operations:
Raise and support the motorcycle.
